hints.content: Start by breaking down the sentence into individual words. You can use the `split` method in most programming languages to achieve this. For example, in Python: `words = sentence.split()`.

Once you have the list of words, remember that you need to check the last character of each word against the first character of the next word. Consider using a loop to iterate through the list of words.
Don't forget to check the last word's last character against the first word's first character as well. This is crucial for the circular condition.
When checking characters, be mindful of case sensitivity. 'A' and 'a' are considered different characters. Make sure to compare them as they are.
Consider edge cases where the sentence consists of only one word. In this case, you only need to check if the last character of the word matches its first character.
Think about how you will handle the indexing when you reach the end of the word list. You can use modulo operations to wrap around to the beginning of the list.

As you implement your checks, ensure that you handle the case where the sentence is empty or consists of only spaces. Although the problem states there will be words, it's good to consider how your code behaves with unexpected inputs.
You might want to use a boolean flag to keep track of whether all conditions have been satisfied as you check each pair of words.
Make sure to return `true` if all checks pass and `false` if any check fails. Pay attention to the return format required by the problem.
Finally, put all the pieces together in a function. Ensure your function takes a string input and returns a boolean value indicating if the sentence is circular.

questionNotes: A sentence consists of words separated by a single space with no leading or trailing spaces.
Words contain only uppercase and lowercase English letters.
The last character of the last word must match the first character of the first word for the sentence to be circular.
